message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s history suggests that he has an alcohol use disorder and is at risk of alcohol withdrawal syndrome after reducing or stopping alcohol intake. The greatest risk for life-threatening effects of alcohol withdrawal is 48-72 hours after the last drink. This is why it is important to monitor patients with alcohol use disorder closely after surgery and to provide appropriate medical management as necessary.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Alcohol withdrawal symptoms typically begin within 6-8 hours of the last drink and peak at 48-72 hours, putting the patient at greatest risk for life-threatening effects during that time frame. The patient's heavy alcohol intake puts him at risk for alcohol withdrawal syndrome, which can include seizures, delirium tremens, and cardiovascular collapse. It is important to monitor the patient closely for signs of withdrawal and provide appropriate intervention as needed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Alcohol withdrawal usually begins 6-24 hours after the last drink, but peak symptoms occur after 48-72 hours. Therefore, the patient is at greatest risk for life-threatening effects of alcohol withdrawal 48-72 hours after his last drink.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Alcohol withdrawal symptoms usually begin within 6-24 hours after the last drink, but the greatest risk for life-threatening effects occurs 48-72 hours after the last drink. This patient's history of heavy alcohol use and the stress of the motor vehicle accident and surgery put him at high risk for alcohol withdrawal.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The risk for life-threatening effects of alcohol withdrawal typically occurs 48-72 hours after the last drink. The patient's history of heavy alcohol use puts him at risk for withdrawal and appropriate monitoring and treatment protocols should be implemented to manage potential withdrawal symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Alcohol withdrawal symptoms peak at around 48-72 hours after the last drink. Therefore, the patient is at greatest risk for life-threatening effects of alcohol withdrawal at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Alcohol withdrawal can occur within 6-12 hours of the last drink but the greatest risk for life-threatening effects is between 48-72 hours after the last drink, when delirium tremens (DTs) may occur.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's history of drinking 1 liter of bourbon daily puts him at risk for alcohol withdrawal syndrome. Symptoms typically begin 6-24 hours after the last drink but peak at 48-72 hours. Therefore, the patient is at the greatest risk for life-threatening effects of alcohol withdrawal 48-72 hours after his last drink.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Alcohol withdrawal syndrome typically starts within 24 hours of the last drink and peak symptoms occur at 48-72 hours. Therefore, the patient is at greatest risk for suffering from life-threatening effects of alcohol withdrawal at 48-72 hours after his last drink.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Alcohol withdrawal symptoms typically appear within 6-24 hours after cessation of drinking, peak at 48-72 hours, and gradually resolve within 5-7 days. Therefore, the patient is at the greatest risk of suffering from life-threatening effects of alcohol withdrawal 48-72 hours after his last drink.
